instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00164: What is 820-00164? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN_L: What is PCH_INTVRMEN_L? PCH_INTVRMEN_L is a signal that stands for Internal Voltage Regulator Enable. When pulled high, this signal enables the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must be pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
I had to combine both logic boards issue in a thread, because they are some what similar. They have similar same issues, missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present
Signals that will make the PCH produce <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> are also present on both boards.                      1.<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> -3.3V
2. <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
3. <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
4. <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
5. <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
6. <SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K</SIGNAL>
7. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
8. <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.3V
9. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3V
10. <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V
11. <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V.
Sometimes, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is intermittently present, but if I withdraw power and restore it, it goes missing again. I'd appreciate your input.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
Please, do not mix the boards.
Same symptom doesn't imply the same cause.

When the <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is high, which coils get voltage?
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> goes high at same time?

Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>3_L</SIGNAL> should pulse at same time.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
Good day
You were right, I shouldn't have mixed board, I sincerely apologise for that. I also made a typo error, the first board was <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B.
 
For the macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B
-With Charger plugged in fan spins temporarily and stops.
-Triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> , charger light changed from amber to green and back to amber, got a fan spin temporarily and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> went high temporarily. Both fan spin and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> occured simultaneously. 
-As for the coils, I'm not sure what coils to check, pls can you specify for me what coils to check.


For the macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
- With charger plugged in nothing happened 
- Triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>,  there was no reaction at all
- I rechecked the those signals that will bring about <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> 
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> is 2.3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> was alsi 2.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>  was 3V they were not up to 3.3V
All other voltages was present and they were 3.3V

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board should restart two times, before stays on; like its 13" sister (3437).

Supposing that you've triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> with <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads (no keyboard connected), seems to have a problem with <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, or its <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> input; check its level.

Open new thread for 00164 board.
Post there all the information mentioned above...

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
Understood, will open another thread for <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
Th <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL>  is high at 3.2V, I will check <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> for drop pulse, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> stay high and <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> went low when I triggered <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards

Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: Changed the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>, the board comes on most of the times, let's say it comes on 7 times out of 10times, but during those times it does not come on if I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> it comes back on.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards

Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: Apologies, I don't understand what you mean, pls can you rephrase, "Check <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR>, traces and solders"??

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> must have 0 ohm and check its trace to pin 3/<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> is 0.4 ohm, which is approximately 0 ohm, there's good continuity from pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> to pin 3 of <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. Tried triggering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>, there's fan spin and it stays on. But it does not stays on when charger plugged.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: Machine must go on by itself plugging charger, only if battery is not present.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message: Yes, battery was not present during these tests

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> MUST stay high when you press power button.
If drops but <SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> stays high (no drop pulse at all), then the problem is around <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00164</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on both boards
threads.message:
Good day 2informaticos
Still on this system
I changed the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>.
It worked for a while and went back to where we started from.
If I trigger <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R5101</RESISTOR> the fan will just spin temporarily and stop.
